I thought it would be a valuable exercise to return to the original message=
 in this thread and try attacking the problem again, since we now know what=
 we're all talking about.

<snip />
>I wouldn't want to do this for every t=
est, and it ought be user optional,
>but I could see it as being a big bene=
fit. I am sure there is some fancier
>OO way to explain/implement this [or =
even a nicer introspection way to
>determine this], but something like a Te=
stCase.setDependency(Class
>testClass) so TestCase constructors mark what t=
hey'd like to depend upon.
>[For introspection maybe a public Class[] getDe=
pendencies()
>interface/method].

To implement this appears to require:

* =
Adding a TestListener that knows when to mark a dependent test case as "do =
not bother executing"
* Storing the dependency list somewhere

You could us=
e JUnit-addons' Test Runner, which flexibly allows you to add your own Test=
Listener. You could implement the MarkDependentTestDoomedTestListener in ab=
out ten lines of code.

The dependency list seems to me to be equally easil=
y stored in the TestCase itself or outside it. If you want it in the TestCa=
se, then simply subclass TestCase, add the data then change the superclasse=
s of your tests. Annoying, but you only have to do it once.

>The test runn=
er engine would need to "sort" the calling order be dependency
>tree, and w=
ould need to know when not to call something, perhaps
>introducing
>a new s=
tate ("deferred" -- meaning not run due to a dependency
>failure/error -- t=
o add to "fail", "error".)

The sorting part is not easy. Maybe I just don'=
t know the algorithms well enough. Either way, you describe a new test runn=
er, which is not part of the framework anyway. Maybe you can subclass JUnit=
-addons' Test Runner to achieve the right effect.

What do you think of thi=
s? You can leverage JUnit-addons instead of rewriting the test runner from =
scratch. You can graft the dependency graph feature by subclassing TestCase=
 and adding a collection of dependent tests.

Any better?


J. B. Rainsberg=
